data.title: “Things and Others” chapter 17: the Universal Exhibition of 1900
data.meta_description: Master Jean-Claude Renard tells us about the remarkable participation of the Faïencerie de Gien in the Universal Exhibition in Paris in 1900.
data.text:
In this 17th chapter of the Chronique Giennoise “Things and Others”, Maître Jean-Claude Renard tells you about the memorable participation of the Faïencerie de Gien in the Universal Exhibition in 1900.

The Manufacture made its mark on the history of Gien by manufacturing monumental pieces for theParis Universal Exhibition, at the Grand Palais and at the Petit Palais on the Champs-Elysées, inaugurated by the President of the French Republic Emile Loubet the 14 1900 April.

Remaining engraved in all memories as the apogee of the Belle Epoque, this event will mark the historic journey of the Faïencerie de Gien, also a member of the jury and triumphant out of competition.

The stand with many pieces is dominated by a large zodiacal clock called a candelabra vase. Electricity is present in this achievement. With a height of 3,60 meters, this work of Louis XIV-style sits on a triangular base sheath. From the top of its capital fall three sconces decorated with scrolls and falling foliage. The terrace bears three Cupids energetically holding the celestial vault, in which are installed the dial and the clockwork movement. A Cupid carrying a torch is seated on the globe. All the Cupids are sculptures of Mathurin Moreau.

– Thanks to the Musée de la Faïencerie de Gien for this photo of the clock –

The stand with many pieces is dominated by a large zodiacal clock called a candelabra vase. Electricity is present in this achievement. With a height of 3,60 meters, this work of Louis XIV-style sits on a triangular base sheath. From the top of its capital fall three sconces decorated with scrolls and falling foliage. The terrace bears three Cupids energetically holding the celestial vault, in which are installed the dial and the clockwork movement. A Cupid carrying a torch is seated on the globe. All the Cupids are sculptures of Mathurin Moreau.

The technique used is also reproduced by many artists in Gien: it consists of the application of colored alkaline enamels, partitioned with the use of gold leaf under enamel.

It should be noted that two vases of different decorations of the same quality accompany the clock. These productions can be seen at the Museum of Faience in Gien.
